The Trump government plays on words by reversing the "Commission of Use" tax. This direct debit on interest makes it possible to avoid international tax treaties. In practice, it is only foreign investors who pay. Disguised discrimination.

As Brad Setser has recently shown it on the social network Threads, more than half of American debt holders-holders of United States Treasury bonds-are individuals or American companies ... who are likely to be spared by this defect. So who else has this debt? Two governments are at the top of the list: Japan and China.

China: 4 % of American bonds

Japan is still an allied country for the time being and could be exempt. Even if the Trump administration shows less enthusiasm towards Europe and its historic partners, the geopolitical alliance with the United States could still play a role.

China, on the other hand, still holds around 4 % of American obligations in circulation. If this figure may seem low, it represents a considerable sum. More importantly, China has money at stake, with more than $ 700 billion placed in its official exchange reserves, probably higher, taking into account unofficial reserves. Chinese semi-public institutions, such as banks and large companies, potentially hold even higher amounts.

Read More: the main world creditor China, one more fragility for emerging and developing countries

Brad Setser recently indicated on threads that China gradually reduces its assets to American treasury bills. We do not know the exact amounts sold, but the transactions passing through Euroclear, in Belgium, offer an overview. Since 2014, China is actually seems to gradually disengage from the US dollar. It has gone from a creditor with 18 % of American shares to a little more than 4 % today.

China remains the second foreign holder of American bonds. Imagine now that Doge's geniuses or others close to Trump decide, for reasons of domestic policy, a selective defect in China.

Premises with Ukraine

Geopolitics could play in two directions. China would reduce its exhibition before ideologues close to Trump took the initiative. Alternatively, she would pursue her own geopolitical objectives by preventing this risk preventively in the event of future tensions.

Russia also liquidated all of its American obligations before invading Ukraine. The risk of selective defect or financial attack was too large. When I was at the Central Bank, my colleagues and I only realized it after the invasion, although the information was before our eyes (which we had presented in an article after the fact).

Towards a sale of American bonds?

China still has a large amount of American bonds. If she hesitated to undertake this daring geopolitical maneuver, she would approach a situation where, from a financial point of view, the green light would be given. The idea of ​​a selective defect could thus accelerate sales of American bonds by China.

If a selective defect should actually occur, the geopolitical consequences would not necessarily be the first concern. It would mean above all that the very gasoline of financial investments worldwide would be upset. The obligations of the American treasury represent, by definition, the safest asset available, according to macroeconomics.

If this active active person who was to fail, capital would immediately seek refuge elsewhere without necessarily finding it. For example, there are not enough German treasury bills, and those from other countries are more risky. This corresponds precisely to the definition of a global financial crisis. We are certainly not there yet. But if the Trump administration was to experiment with selective faults as it does with customs duties, the consequences would be much more catastrophic and immediate.

Title: We inherit the genetics of our parents, but what about epigenetics?
Description:
Epigenetic marks are DNA chemical changes that will allow certain genes to be activated or extinguished. They are reproduced when the cells divide but can they be between two generations?

Based on genetic information, DNA is the founding molecule of earthly life. However, it cannot work alone, because its information must be interpreted by proteins present in the nucleus of cells, adding additional information that is called epigenetic information ("epis" from the Greek prefix which means "above").

At each generation, we inherit the DNA contained in the chromosomes of our two parents, in the form of 23 chromosomes of the mother and 23 chromosomes of the father, to lead to the 46 chromosomes of the human species (this number varies according to the species) in each of our cells. During development, our cells divide a very large number of times to train adult individuals (made up of more than 30,000 billion cells!).

The equation seems relatively simple, because the DNA sequence of the 46 chromosomes is identically copied (during the "replication of DNA") before sharing fairly in two "girls" cells during each cell division (called "mitosis"). Despite this identical genetic information, our cells are not all the same. Each of them differentiates to produce the variety of tissues and organs that constitute our body. It is precisely epigenetic information that allows this differentiation.

"Brand-tags" in our genome

What do we know about these epigenetic mechanisms that have been the subject of intense research since the beginning of the century? They involve a large number of cellular factors, the function of which is started to understand. Within chromosomes, DNA, negatively loaded, wraps a positively loaded protein, histones. Hundreds of factors bind, directly to DNA or histones, to form what one could qualify as "epigenetic sheath".

Read more: epigenetics, inactivation of the X chromosome and women's health: Conversation with Edith Heard

This sheath is far from homogeneous. It contains factors which can deposit, on the DNA molecule or histones, small molecules which act as "bookmarks" that could be put in a book in specific places. These are the famous "epigenetic marks" (methylations, acetylations ...) and a large number of them are found at the genes that are located throughout our chromosomes. These marks are essential, they differ in the different cell types composed by an organism and contribute directly to the regulation of the expression of genes (for example, important genes for the function of the liver will be expressed in the liver cells, while the specific genes of neurons or muscle cells will be extinguished). The question is now whether these epigenetic mechanisms also influence the transmission of genetic information.

First, take the simplest case of mitosis (cell division). Most cells must transmit their function, that is, reproduce the expression of the panoply of genes that are their own in their daughter cells. A large upheaval occurs during mitosis with a significant grouping and condensation of chromosomes and therefore of the DNA that compose them. During this stage, DNA remains wrapped around histones, but many proteins in the sheath are dissociated. On the other hand, most brands on DNA and histones are preserved. Thus, epigenetic landmarks will remain on and around DNA. Once mitosis is completed, these brands will allow girls to quickly reconstruct the architecture of genes along the chromosomes, which will still carry the essential epigenetic brands and will again be able to recruit the factors associated with their function. The epigenetic mechanisms therefore participate directly in the inheritance of the cellular function.

Could this epigenetic information also be transmitted to future generations? In this case, the challenge is much more important. The information must be transmitted to the male and female gametes which merge during fertilization to form the first cell of the embryo. This cell will be divided in order to constitute the different cellular types of the future organism. The stages of reorganization and condensation of chromosomes are here even more drastic than during mitosis. The methylation of DNA, the brands of histones and the 3D organization of the chromosomes are largely reprogrammed, as if the body was trying to erase the epigenetic baggage accumulated in the previous generation.

Epigenetic transmissions in certain species

Can epigenetics nevertheless influence the genetic heritage of descendants? Today, this question is the subject of intensive, and sometimes controversial research. This research intends in particular to understand whether environmental, nutritional, stress or exposure to chemical or physical factors could exert influence on future generations.

We have been able to describe precise examples of the effect of the environment on epigenetic regulation in many animal and plant species.

In reptiles, temperature is a major determinant of the sexual type, via the deposit of specific epigenetic brands (methylation of histones). In insects, many phenotypic features are linked to diets that cause epigenetic variations, for example the distinction between the queen and workers 'bees or the distinction of workers' caste in certain ants (via DNA methylation and acetylation of histones, respectively).

Exposure to chemical factors, such as arsenic or bisphenol A can also cause epigenetic changes. We are trying today to understand the mechanisms by which these stimuli act and if they can generate a stable heritage over the generations in the human species. Epidemiological studies have tried to make links between diet and influence on offspring, but these studies often confront multi-factory aspects that are difficult to control and suffer from a lack of molecular evidence.

Studies in terms of model organizations are therefore necessary to study the influence of epigenetic changes on the transmission of genetic information. Examples of transmission of epigenetic states through generations are currently well described in the vercation of C.Elegans and plants, organisms where there is less reprogramming of the epigenetic state during fertilization. Our team is working on the model Drosophila Melanogaster or vinegar fly. Following disturbances of the 3D organization of chromosomes, we were able to highlight cases of inheritance of epigenetic modifications on a gene responsible for the color of the eye over many generations.

In the mouse model, studies have also shown that the insertion of genetic elements made it possible to induce epigenetic changes, in particular DNA methylation. These modifications lead to the repression of a gene responsible for the color of the coat or important genes of the metabolism which, when they are suppressed, cause obesity or hypercholesterolemia, and this, inheritablely on several generations.

In these examples of transgenerational inheritance, the first signal which induces an epigenetic change implies the modification of a small DNA sequence. Even if this sequence is restored to normal, the change is maintained. Although probably rare and possibly influenced by genetic heritage, these phenomena could exist in nature. Future research will be necessary to understand if other epigenetic mechanisms could be inherited.

Although this data does not change current genetic laws, they indicate that beyond the simple duplication and transmission of the DNA sequence to male and female gametes, epigenetic information could contribute to the inheritance of certain traits in many species. This research could therefore be used to better understand the evolution and adaptation of species, as well as mechanisms at the basis of certain human pathologies, such as cancers.

Title: Between Trump expansionism and Danish post-colonialism, what security architecture for Greenland?
Description:
Donald Trump wants to annex Greenland, in the apparent indifference, even with the consent of Vladimir Putin. Denmark refuses to sell its autonomous territory, whose inhabitants recently brought a coalition in power in which three out of four parties are independentists. Beyond the challenges linked to the natural riches of the immense Arctic Island, what is played out here is also the defense of Greenland, now provided by the United States as part of NATO.

In January 2025, President Trump proclaimed the will of the United States to take control of Greenland and threatens Denmark, whose island is an autonomous territory, of economic or military retaliatory measures if his requirement is not satisfied.

These words shock European, Danish and Greenlandic political leaders. Washington’s openly expansionist posture calls into question the transatlantic link, and with it, security architecture for Greenland. In response, the French Minister of Foreign Affairs and Europe, Jean-Noël Barrot, but also the president of the Military Committee of the European Union, Robert Brieger, suggests at the end of January the sending of European troops to Greenland.

These unanimous convictions are not enough to discourage the new team in place in the White House. In March, the project of visit to Nuuk, the capital, and Sisimiut, the second city of Greenland, of an American delegation led by Vice-President J. D. Vance, without official invitation, was strongly condemned by the Danish and Greenlandic authorities. On March 26, Donald Trump cynically proclaimed in the oval office that the world needs the United States to have Greenland, and that Denmark must yield Greenland to the United States.

Faced with the Danish and Greenlandic protests, the visiting program of the American delegation is revised downwards, but the symbol remains strong: it is at the American space base of Pituffik that J. D. Vance went on March 28.

Washington and the Defense of Greenland

So far, it is above all the United States that ensures the safety of Greenland. But it should not be forgotten that it is at the request of NATO that they manage the Pituffik base (named Thule until 2023), from the 1951 defense agreement signed with Denmark - amended in 2004 to include Greenland as a partner. This agreement does not question the sovereignty in Greenland in the Kingdom of Denmark in question in question, sovereignty that the United States has already recognized in 1916.

It is also NATO members who, with the Northern Viking exercises, strengthen their position in the Giuk area (Greenland, Iceland and United Kingdom), which has become a major strategic concern due to the projection of naval power of Russia.

However in an astounding statement made on March 27 at the Arctic International Forum in Mourmansk, Vladimir Putin seemed to support the American project for annexation of the territory: "It is," he is, "serious projects on the part of the United States with regard to Greenland. These projects have ancient historical roots. "He specifies:" Greenland is a question which concerns two specific countries. It has nothing to do with us. »»

Does the economic rapprochement desired by Moscow and Washington in the context of the negotiations on the war in Ukraine could ramifications in the Arctic? Kirill Dmitriev, adviser to President Putin for foreign investments and economic cooperation, says: "We are open to cooperation in investment in the Arctic. It could be logistics or other areas beneficial for Russia and the United States. "But before concluding agreements," he adds, the war in Ukraine must end. »»

The growing involvement of Greenland in its safety

Danish Prime Minister puts Frederiksen, wants to believe that the transatlantic link remains solid. However, if the weakening of this link raises questions on the security of Greenland, the march of the autonomous territory towards independence introduces another factor.

Cécile Pelaudeix, provided by the author

Greenland security is inevitably determined by its relationship with the old colonial power. Today, Greenland is independent in several areas of administration, but security and defense in particular remain the responsibility of Denmark. However, the Greenlandic government, the Nalalakkersuisut, would like to be more and more involved in decision -making relating to these areas. Hoping for economic benefits and the valuation of local knowledge, it aspires to gradually take charge of certain aspects of the security policy.

The autonomous territory was consulted for the first time significantly on defense issues during the implementation of the defense agreement concluded on January 27, 2025 between the Government of Denmark and the parties represented in the Danish Parliament, worth 2 billion euros. The agreement intends to improve surveillance, the affirmation of sovereignty and societal resilience in the region, supporting the allies and the NATO mission. The parties also want to strengthen cooperation in intelligence and research and modernize the installations of the joint arctic command in Nuuk. To this end, three new arctic patrol ships are planned.

In this context, the results of the legislative elections held in Greenland on March 11 report a marked desire for strengthened economic development allowing access to independence.

A new government in a critical moment in the history of Greenland

The two parties that have dominated the political life of Greenland for 50 years, the leftist ecological party Inuit Ataqatigiit (AI) and the Social Democratic Party Siumut, saw their support combined falling in half for the benefit of the center of Law Demokraatit (29.9 % of the votes), favorable to a liberal economic policy in Greenland, in particular for the sector of the populist Naleraq (24.5 %). Like all Greenlandic parties with the exception of Atassut (liberal-conservative party having collected 7.5 % in the last legislative elections), Naleraq wishes the independence of Greenland but it claims immediate independence. The large government coalition formed on March 27 brings together the DEMOKRAATIT, Inuit Ataqatigiit, SIUMUT and ATASSUT parties, but it excludes Naleraq, a decision that translates the desire not to weaken the future of Greenland at a time when Washington hammers its desire to get its hands on the island.

During his campaign, the Demokraatit party insisted that Greenland was not for sale, while wishing independence of Greenland supported by a free association with Denmark or with the United States. The free association designates international agreements between small states and a great power which guarantees them significant security, defense and financial assistance, such as the 1986 free association treaty, which governs relations between the United States and the Pacific micro-states such as Micronesia, the Marshall Islands and the Palaos. This option seems to have long been firing while anti-American demonstrations take place in front of the United States Consulate in Nuuk. IA and SIUMUT recommend participation in NATO in addition to Danish national defense, stating that Greenland could sit within the NATO parliamentary assembly.

The majority of Greenland women and politicians are looking for a security partnership that complements that which exists between autonomous territory and Denmark. This desire for a post-colonial arrangement is also clearly reflected in the search for a diversification of economic partners with, for example, Iceland, the United Kingdom, the United States and Asian countries. The European Union does not appear in a protruding way in the proposals of political parties, perhaps because of the agreements already signed under the 1985 Greenland Treaty which associates Greenland and the EU. The EU pays 13.5 million euros each year to Greenland to open its waters to EU fishing ships, and 3 million euros to support sustainable fishing. In addition, there are 225 million euros for the period 2021-2027 to support green education and growth.

With regard to raw materials, the EU and Greenland signed in November 2023 a strategic partnership agreement, in the form of a memorandum of understanding aimed at establishing sustainable value chains for raw materials. Naaja H. Nathanielsen, then Minister of Foreign Affairs, Trade, Mineral Resources, Justice and Gender Equality of Greenland, said that this agreement would be supported by a roadmap in order to guarantee concrete results enjoying the two parties, but that the EU should encourage Member States to invest.

In terms of defense and security, Greenland options are not so varied. In addition to counting on the United States and Denmark, they consist of two non-exclusive possibilities: NATO and European defense.

Limited scenarios requiring the Greenland agreement

For the Greenlanders who want to be masters of their destiny, any exclusive dependence on the United States is problematic. According to a recent survey, 85 % of them oppose American policy in the matter.

Based exclusively on NATO could also be an uncertain decision. If the United States withdraws from NATO, as Trump has threatened it several times, the legitimization of its management of the Pituffik base would disappear. And if the United States no longer constitutes reliable insurance against the projection of the naval power of Russia and its hybrid threats, but rather threaten Greenland itself as they do insistently, European partners and the capacities of the European Union come into play. States that participated in the Northern Viking exercises-Norway, the United Kingdom and France-would certainly become more important actors Even, possibly, that Iceland, which certainly has no clean armed forces but represents an "insubmersible aircraft carrier".

Whatever the options selected, they will only be relevant to the security of Greenland only if they are chosen freely by the Greenlandic people. Between the threat of American expansionism and the post-colonial context, it is perhaps the EU, with its legal structure and its values, which could offer the Groenlanders the best chance of determining their security in their own terms.

Title: Umbrella and panic: false evidence on the renuclearization and remilitarization of Europe
Description:
The cause seems to be understood: the extension to the allies of France of French nuclear deterrence and the massive conventional rearmament of the continent are largely presented, both by the leaders of the country and by most of the media, as almost imperative solutions in the face of the Russian threat and the disengagement of the United States of the defense of the continent. However, the evidence of this necessity collapses as soon as we study the strategic communication campaign that produces it. This is the first step necessary for a serious reflection on a French and European defense strategy.

In recent weeks, the media has largely presented the establishment of a European nuclear deterrence coupled with the conventional EU rearmament (Ursula von der Leyen has announced in this regard a target of expenditure of 800 billion euros over four years) as obviously desirable or even necessary responses to the Russian threat and to American disengagement. This is a strategic communication operation that manifests itself at least three ways, detailed here in order to allow you to recognize them. We therefore leave aside the evaluation of the Russian threat, which deserves an analysis in its own right, to focus on the proposed responses and the production of illusions of obviousness and necessity. As soon as we stop being seduced by these false evidences, a serious strategic reflection on the defense of France and Europe will be able to begin.

Read More: Faced with nuclear danger, the effects of a casual expert discourse

Reverse the meaning of words to create illusions of protective and defense

You can hear from articles talking about "nuclear umbrella", "protection", even "nuclear shield". Big news at least sixty-five years: nothing like it exists.

The umbrella is able to keep us dry when the rain falls. If the nuclear rain had to fall, there would be no umbrella, any nationality whatsoever. At least since the coupling of ballistic missiles impossible to intercept on thermonuclear explosives in the 1950s and the early 1960s, we remain at the mercy of the technological accident and the determination of the enemy who would like to take the risk of suffering a response. However, the arsenal of Russia is dimensioned from notions such as the limitation of damage (that is to say the destruction of the greatest possible number of enemy weapons before they can be launched against Moscow); If the deterrence was to fail, having nuclear weapons on our soil would transform us into a priority target.

Likewise, offering our umbrella to others does not commit us to commit a violent act for him or her. On the contrary, to offer a "nuclear umbrella" is to commit to using nuclear force, with the consequences that we know, if an ally was attacked. Besides the problem that for the ally either there is no umbrella and that the credibility of such a promise is very questionable, it is a question here of committing to committing an act of great violence and being ready to undergo the consequences or to lose its credibility.

Finally, the umbrella makes us strictly independent of the variations in the weather. He shelters us whatever happens. But in the world of ballistic missiles, we remain entirely dependent on the will of the most hostile enemy who would be ready to run the risk of the response and the possibility that remains accidental launch in any country that targets France.

The metaphor of the umbrella describes the desired effects of the proposed policy, not its effects. Those who use it either ignore a known reality for 65 years, or overthrow reality by repeating the elements of language of official discourse and by presenting intentions as proven effects.

Coupled with the qualification of the French nuclear arsenal by the term "deterrence" and the assertion of the possibility of "strategic autonomy" in a nuclearized world, these three reversals create illusions of protection and defense in a vulnerability. In reality, we remain at the mercy of both the accident and the most hostile enemy.

Do not assess the perverse effects of the proposed political response

The second sign that the voices carrying this discourse make strategic communication is that they do not care about the possible perverse effects of the proposed policy. The only limit mentioned commonly is the problem of credibility, which would require producing more French nuclear weapons and relaunching the creation of fissile materials.

However, any political scientist knows that no policy leads to all of their desired effects and only their desired effects. To make it believe that is precisely to do communication. What are the plausible perverse effects of this policy?

First, historically, since these proposals had the effect of relegitating the French nuclear arsenal and justifying investments in the field, this could help fuel the arms race by creating new targets usable by our opponents to justify the increase in their arsenals.

Then proclaim that a nuclear arsenal is necessary for the security of the continent reaffirms the desirability of nuclear weapons and makes it more difficult to conduct a credible and efficient non-proliferation policy, to which France is attached.

In addition, relaunching the industrial machine to manufacture weapons will increase the carbon footprint of France and the European Union, whose actions are deemed insufficient to keep their commitments in the fight against global warming.

In addition, the rise in water and the climate change that is accelerating will require increased spending to protect each nuclear weapon, and therefore a fortiori each additional nuclear weapon if the arsenal should expand. These weapons will therefore be costs of opportunity in a context of rare resources and increasing needs.

In addition, it would be necessary to identify precisely the actors benefiting from these policies. Let us not forget, in fact, that the investment in the armament had a much lower civilian training effect that announced; that suspicions of corruption have been put forward in the sector; That Thalès, Dassault and Mbda, direct beneficiaries of the announced plan, are still under a complaint of 2022 for complicity in crimes against humanity and war crimes in the context of the war in Yemen, and more recent suspicions relating to the use of the weapons they sold in Israel, which employed them against Palestinian civilians.

Finally, the renuclearization and remilitarization of the European continent, advanced in the name of the fight against the Russian threat, if they were to take place, would only bear fruit in a few years and, therefore, could be directly counterproductive. Indeed, in Slovakia, Hungary, Romania and perhaps in France, pro-Russian parties are probable supporters of power during the next electoral deadlines ... and therefore the beneficiaries of weapons built to undo their political project.

Produce illusions of absence of alternative and virtuous sacrifice of our environmental commitments

Third index revealing the current communication operation: the ambient speech does not explore alternatives, as if the only one was the abandonment of Ukraine. While the rearmament produced and coincides with an abandonment of our environmental commitments, this appears as a virtuous sacrifice in the name of the defense of Ukraine. However, there is no dilemma between respecting our energy sobriety commitments and support for kyiv or the security of the European continent in the face of the Russian threat. We can see it as soon as we stop reducing the possible assistance to Ukraine and security to the supply or possession of weapons.

It is obvious that European Russian hydrocarbon purchases allow the Kremlin to finance the war and its army, so that the reduction of these purchases is, in itself, aid to Ukraine. The margin of improvement in terms of reducing the Russian hydrocarbon bill and helping Ukraine without sacrificing our commitments in the fight against climate change is considerable. It appears as soon as we observe that, as shown in a study by the Center for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA) in March 2025, since February 2022 the 27 EU Member States bought for more than 205 billion euros in Russian hydrocarbons, more than four times the 49.2 billion euros of military aid provided to Ukraine.

The EU claims that it has emancipated Russian hydrocarbons, but a substantial margin remains. Almost 40 % of hydrocarbons purchased by EU27 countries in India, China and Turkey in the first three quarters of 2024 are of Russian origin. Just over the first four months of 2024, France bought 600 million euros in liquefied natural gas from Russia.

It is wrong to say that the defense of Ukraine demands to sacrifice our climate commitments. On the contrary, progress in the direction of reducing dependence on fossil fuels would benefit Ukraine by reducing our indirect financial contribution to the Russian war effort.

Three conclusions: identify communicators as such, keep our climate commitments and conduct a serious strategic analysis

In conclusion, the media saturation relating to the "European nuclear umbrella" coupled with the remilitarization of France and the continent to all the characteristics of a strategic communication operation which falls under intoxication. The diagnosis of this poisoning operation has three opportunities.

First, it makes it possible to distinguish the lobbyists/communicators from analysts. Only the former can make all the errors identified in this article: naturalization of the elements of language of the Official Speech Pro-Armement (nuclear) as categories of analysis ("nuclear umbrella", "deterrence", the possibility of "protection"), acceptance of affirmations of the desired effects of policies as proof of their proven effects, and lack of consideration of alternative policies or proposed.

These criteria thus make it possible to sort between strategic communication and admissible defense of the proposed policy, which would require not to commit any of these faults. Added to this is the identification of the conflicts of interest of those who express themselves, many of the votes that defend "European nuclear deterrence" resulting from institutions with a direct conflict of interest and an explicit role in the promotion of the national nuclear arsenal. The conflict of interest is not necessary for the characterization of communicator/lobbyist, but it constitutes an indicator suggesting a bias.

Then, alternatives, compatible with the holding of our environmental commitments, exist and must be explored.

Finally, climatic, strategic and democratic requirements all call for impartial strategic reflection, which refuses funding conflict of interest, rejects the faults identified above and recognizes the multiplicity of existential threats that we face.

Title: How the ingenuity of "service plants" can help reduce pesticides
Description:
In plants there are dozens of mechanisms more ingenious than each other to naturally regulate organisms that attack cultures. Based on these precious allies is essential to reduce our dependence on pesticides. This also makes it possible to build more resilient agroecological systems.

Each gardener knows the Indian carnation, an ally that keeps insects and diseases from the vegetable patch away. But did you know that there are many other plants, called "service plants", precious for agriculture more respectful of health and the environment?

Research results reveal that a wide range of plants, when they are integrated into cultivation systems, are capable of regulating field bioagressers (insects and arthropods, nematodes, fungi, bacteria, viruses, weeds), and therefore to reduce pesticide needs.

Depending on the plants, they mobilize a particular mechanism or combine several. Some will act against aerial bioagressors, such as aromatic plants or corn. Others are effective against telluric bioagressors, such as crotalant, hybrid sorghum or crucifers.

Create conducive conditions

Let us initially look at the mechanisms implemented by certain plants to counter air bioagresseurs.

The refuge plants, frequently established on the edge of the plot, provide a housing favorable to the auxiliaries, providing them with the cottage and the cover. Thus, the latter are already present when pests arrive to attack cultures, they intervene faster (predation, parasitism). This is particularly the case with the Mexican sunflower (Tithonia diversifolia) used near sugar cane fields in Tanzania to attract and predict the predatory ladybugs of the yellow sipha flava aphor, a major devastating in this country.

Jacques Avelino, CIRAD, UMR Phim, supplied by the author

Shading plants, integrated into the plot, modify its microclimate. By changing the brightness and humidity, they make climatic conditions unfavorable to certain organisters and more favorable to others.

This is particularly the case for eucalyptus or erythrines in coffee plantations, vis-à-vis the Kahawae Colletotrichum mushroom causing the anthracnosis of the berries in Cameroon. These plants have the same effect on the Placococcus citri cochet and the Cercle Coffeicola mushroom which causes Costa Rica to Cercle.

Create natural barriers

Some plants play a barrier role against attackers. Located on the edge, they form a vegetable curtain which prevents pests from reaching culture. This is the case of the barriers of Crotalaria JUncea which obstruct the passage of the Aleurodes, which fly to the height of man towards the pepper plants.

Other plants also use space to curb the enemy's progress. Associated with a sensitive culture, they will hide the latter from pests by creating a visual "dilution" effect. These associations, by generating spatial discontinuity, can also slow the propagation of close to fungal diseases.

They can also regulate weeds by competition for resources (light, water, nutrients) or by physical barrier. In banana groves, species like Neonotonia Wightii or Arachis Pintoi have revealed good skills, with a moderate impact on the growth of banana trees.

Inspired by Ratnadass et al., 2011

Issue repellent or attractive odors

Plants emitting odors can be used alone or combined to increase their effectiveness in a "push-power" system:

The "push" plant, integrated into the middle of the culture, diffuses a "repellant perfume" for pests. Aromatic plants, such as basil or the big West Indian thyme Plectronicus, constitute an interesting pool of "push" plants.

CIRAD UPR HORTSYS, supplied by the author

At the same time, a "sweater" plant is introduced, either in the plot to attract the auxiliaries, or by the edge to attract the devastating towards it, thus diverting it from culture. Thus, certain varieties of gentle corn attract the female of the tomato night which, instead of laying on tomatoes, will do it on the silks of corn ears - which constitute "dead ends" because the larvae that hatch cannot develop there.

Interrupt the reproduction of the enemy

The plants mentioned so far only attacked aerial organic bioagressors. But other mechanisms exist to fight telluric bioagressors.

The rotation of cultures, in particular, makes it possible to interrupt the reproduction of bioagressors. When a plant not sensitive to the aggressor replaces the sensitive plant for a period, the population of parasites in the soil decreases sharply.

Paula Fernandes, CIRAD, UPR HORTSYS, supplied by the author

Once the sensitive culture returns to the plot, it is able to develop without major incidence as long as the pathogenic population remains low. A real speed race then engages between the development of culture and the multiplication of pathogen.

This is for example the case in market gardening or banana groves. Create sanitizing fallows based on non-host species (such as Crotalaria JUncea or Brachiaria SPP) reduce populations of phytoparasite nematodes.

Poisoning or inhibition

Another method of attack on telluries, poisoning or inhibition - also called allelopathy. Here, different strategies exist and have been highlighted.

Certain plants, such as crotalant, release toxic pyrrolizidinic alkaloids via their roots for several species of phytoparasite nematodes.

Another means is bio -feum by certain plants at the time of their decomposition. For example, isothiocyanates, sulfur compounds with a broad spectrum of efficiency (fungi, bacteria, nematodes, etc.), from the degradation of glucosinolates largely present in brassicaceae (mustard for example) and alliays (garlic, onion, etc.).

Other plants, finally, cause the germination of the seeds of parasitic plants (such as striga) or attract pathogens (phytoparasite nematodes) to their roots by emitting signals similar to those of a sensitive plant. Thus, cotton, linen or soy, non -host plants, decrease the infectious potential of the soil by generating the “suicidal” germination of the Striga, whose radicles are then unable to settle in their roots.

In general, service plants can also play a beneficial role by stimulating the diversity of microflora and macrofauna of the soil, in a global or targeted manner.

Delete bioagressors

Among the soil communities are antagonistic or predatory species of the organices. In particular certain free nematodes, which feed on phytoparasite nematodes. But also bacteria and fungi, which can produce antibiotics or even parasitize these bioagresseurs. We then speak of specific suppressiveness.

In banana groves, the fallows of Paspalum notatum thus increase the populations of omnivorous or predators free nematodes, which in return decrease the populations of phytoparasite nematodes.

Other soil microorganisms, without directly regulating pathogens, occupy niches where they are in competition with them, in particular by colonizing the rhizosphere of plants, and using the same resources.

In doing so, they reduce the conditions favorable to the growth of pathogens. We then speak of general suppressiveness.

Enrich the ground

In addition to increasing populations beneficial of the soil, service plants also help to enrich it. Often used as green fertilizers or roofing plants, they restore organic matter to the ground and nutrients, then accessible to the cultivated plant.

Due to improving its physiological resistance, via a more balanced nutrition and the availability of certain trace elements, it is less vulnerable to the attacks on organic, telluric but also air.

The effectiveness of service plants therefore depends to a large extent of the context. To succeed, the use of service plants to manage bioagresseurs requires a clear understanding of the generic principles of agroecology coupled with fine knowledge of the species involved, in order to adapt and apply these principles to specific situations.

The evolution of interactions between cultures and organicians also requires adapting practices to change, and, if necessary, to simultaneously mobilize various measures and mechanisms of regulation.

Title: Censor or protect children? Youth books, a "literature under surveillance"
Description:
The cancellation by the Ministry of National Education of its order for an adaptation of the Beauty and the Beast for CM2 students has sparked a controversy which invites you to look at the particular situation of children's literature and the specific attention which is long granted to public space.

The recent case of the "Book for the holidays", as a dismissed Ministry of National Education before its printing in 800,000 copies, surprised a number of players in the book and the school, starting with its author Jul who had adapted the very classic the beautiful and the beast, from Madame Leprince de Beaumont (1711-1776).

The children of CM2 concerned by the operation, which aims to offer them a book to read during the summer before they entered the sixth, will therefore receive another title, but the designer did not hesitate to speak of "censorship" on the part of the General Directorate of School Education, which intervened on March 17.

The big word was pronounced and this controversy highlighted the particular situation of children's literature within the cultural field. This is an exception: it owes its audience to be the only place where censorship is exercised openly in a democracy. This necessary protection of the juvenile reader would even impose itself "naturally", if we believe the Spanish editor Beatriz de Moura.

But this singular status poses a certain number of questions: how does this "censorship" work and from what regulations? On what objects and on which subjects does it exercise?

Children's books, an old control

Since its origins, literature addressed to youth has been a "literature under surveillance", because religion, school and political power have always sought to ensure control.

Religious surveillance refers to very old practices (inquisition and index). It is mainly expressed by interventions of ecclesiastics in the field of literature, such as Father Louis Bethlehem who publishes Romans to read and novels to proscribe. Classification test from the moral point of view of the main novels and novelists (1904). In 1927, a resounding trial targets the abbot, who staged in public "licentious" journals.

The school also exercises control over children's literature. This institutional pressure is exercised in particular on publishers, aware of the role of the school in terms of prescription. The schooling of children's literature shows one of its setbacks here: the power of influence on sales exercised by the teaching authorities and by the teachers themselves.

Political surveillance of children's literature is not recent. From the end of the 19th century, Senator René Bérenger (nicknamed "Father the modesty") created the central protest society against the street license, and the legal arsenal is strengthened with the Outraight Aux Moirs of 1898. Before the Second World War, the law of July 29, 1939 established a family code, of which 20 articles are devoted to the "offense of manners".

The political consensus present at the Liberation is therefore not surprising, since law n ° 49-956 of July 16, 1949 on publications intended for youth is the culmination of a half-century process.

In children's literature, from law to self -censorship

The primary function of law n ° 49-956 of July 16, 1949 on publications intended for youth (mentioned today even in all works intended for childhood) is not to exercise censorship, because it first aims to establish ex ante control based on intimidation.

Indeed, its article 3 provides for a supervisory and control commission, depending on the ministries of justice and the interior and responsible for monitoring the entire production addressed to youth, essentially from the criteria defined in article 2. The Commission receives all the titles to be published and makes opinions, sometimes intervening with publishers. According to the formula of researcher Pascal Durand, this law therefore organizes the "submission of [authors and publishers] on a normative horizon", which will be described as "self -censorship".

Recently, the law has undergone several modifications, notably in its article 2 which defines the disputed questions, but the activity of the commission has "very strongly reduced", if we believe Bernard Joubert who identified the victims in his voluminous dictionary of books and newspapers. Censorship is exerted today much more effectively through private actors to which the media field offers favorable terrain, and the institution now seems to be in the background in terms of impact on the actors of the book.

On the journey of a book, actions of censorship and self -censorship can therefore arise at all stages. At the source, the authors spontaneously assume their share, but few openly talk about it, undoubtedly by will not to harm the legitimacy of their creation.

Author Malika Ferdjoukh thus confided that she deleted a sentence which she considered delicate in a youth novel: "The bee snifles her line of vanilla ice cream. According to her, this free image "seemed to endorse and make it slightly something that is not." In Titus Flaminius: La Fontaine aux Vestales (2003), Jean-François Nahmias resorts to very modest words and the narrative ellipse to evoke the first night of love of his character. In this historical novel where the detailed description of the customs of the time sacrificed to the constraint of the genre, the very chaste evocation of the sexuality of the heroes creates an amazing paradox.

The authors therefore assume their share of self -censorship, sometimes at the cost of literary acrobatics, by "adapting" their text to their audience, concerned that they are to "respect their reader". The publishers intervene secondly, spurred by the legal framework, but especially by the reactions of adult prescribers, who are also their buyers ...

The American influence of "sensitivity readers"

Some publishers come to spontaneously withdraw from the works under the pressure of effective media campaigns such as the one who targeted on the puberty, (Milan editions, collection "Les Secrets des pipelettes"), a documentary intended for pre-teens, published in February 2018. Following a petition collecting 148,000 signatories in three days, the publishing house decides to abandon the whole collection. The researcher Mathilde Lévêque gives a critical and nuanced analysis of this case in an article entitled We caught censorship.

Among the prescribers, the librarians have always taken their share in the obstacles drawn between a book and its readers. The intentional absence in the purchasing list, relegation to "hells" (when they exist) or simply in the office, are frequent practices. In 2016, in 2016, the Fou du body dictionary (2012), from Katy Couprie, was the subject of a withdrawal measure in the network of the city of Paris.

The state apparatus seems to have lost much of its impact today, the actors of the editorial field "merchant" between them - on the media space - the terms of what is now published to youth. The 1949 law remains as a reference in the background, for a publishing sector where pressure groups now occupy first place in terms of interventions followed by effects.

In practice, this situation is more and more like the one that has always prevailed in the United States. The influence of across the Atlantic materializes in the practice of publishers who mobilize "sensitivity readers" and warn their readers with "trigger warnings".

Finally, it should be noted that censorship is almost exclusively thematic and clearly manifests the evolution of societies, through taboo themes that persist (sexuality, violence, political), but also the emergence of new subjects such as gender or race. Another constant appears: the absence of taking into account the narrative aspects in the presentation of the themes deemed delicate.

The role of literary processes mobilized to represent this or that subject has passed over in silence in the vast majority of cases. However, we know how important this aspect is to assess the possible safety of a story, but the censors rush to the content, without wanting to take into account their treatment or the "measures to protect the reader" set up by the authors.

Its research activities meet in a concrete way to priority needs: mitigation and adaptation to climate change, fight against poverty and inequalities, preservation of biodiversity, access to care, taking into account social dynamics. Research questions are developed with players in the field and local populations. The teams meet looks, disciplines and knowledge through long -term partnerships to build robust and high impact solutions.
